title: Before 1 January 2022, will the European Commission (EC) recommend that the Council of the European Union authorize the EC to open negotiations with Taiwan on an investment agreement?
preds: Too close to end of Calendar Year for this to prove true.
While the EU seeks greater cooperation with Taiwan, It still fear angering China. The EU will continue to seek greater cooperation with Taiwan, but not official investment or trade agreement

Probably not in that time frame. Germany needs to form its government and stabilize. France has an election next year. Some still want the investment agreement with China so there is a big counter pressure. Good article. https://www.nysun.com/foreign/europe-is-making-gingerly-an-opening-to-the-free/91738/
This would be a majorly provocative step toward the PRC, and there does not appear to be EU agreement on this course.
@ctsats sounds reasonable. In addition, none of the EU member countries wants to raise a storm with a superpower whose ire in this matter is rather predictable.

Although the European Parliament on Sep 16 reaffirmed its support and reiterated their call for the Commission and the Council to progress on an EU investment agreement with Taiwan (https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20210910IPR11917/parliament-sets-out-its-vision-for-a-new-eu-strategy-on-china), as of Sep 30 there have been no formal developments (https://www.reneweuropegroup.eu/events/2021-07-12/an-investment-agreement-with-taiwan). According to MERICS (https://merics.org/en/merics-briefs/taiwan-indo-pacific-eu-china-policy): > Before the Commission could proceed with plans for the impact assessment and the renaming of the EU office in Taiwan, it must first find significant support from member states. Yet member states reactions to Beijing’s fallout with Vilnius have been relatively low-key as the European capitals continue to exercise caution when discussing forming closer ties with Taiwan.

I'm quoting @LokiOdinevich from another question (https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1875-will-the-people-s-republic-of-china-and-the-eu-sign-a-comprehensive-agreement-on-investment-before-1-january-2022) "
https://www.newsweek.com/eu-lawmakers-ignore-china-protests-seek-stronger-taiwan-ties-1625318
A European Parliament committee adopted a resolution on Wednesday calling for the forging of stronger ties between the European Union and Taiwan, while for the first time warning of China's "military belligerence" against the democratic island and its 23.5 million citizens. The EP's Committee on Foreign Affairs voted 60-to-four in favor of the "EU-Taiwan Relations and Cooperation" report, which calls on the European Commission to assess the possibility of a EU-Taiwan Bilateral Investment Agreement (BIA). Germany and France [are] warned [that] 'selfish' China approach will let Beijing 'divide and conquer' [by random EU parlamentarian]
https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/1485974/Germany-latest-France-news-EU-China-stance-Beijing-Europe-policy-Emmanuel-Macron-latest-VN
"

China is in a bit of strife at the moment. Covid is stopping it from opening its borders because its vaccines are inadequate. It means they face a huge - post Covid lockdown wave - and the risk to stable government that a wave would bring will make it something the CCP will do everything it can to avoid. It will stay lockdown "forever". 
Which in a way suits the CCP, because I suspect it has no intention of ever opening up to the world again. It wants to keep its people locked down within its borders, and perhaps even locked down within their provinces. Ostensibly on the grounds of stopping Covid's spread. But the real reason, is managing the spread of dangerous ideas. 
It's gambling that its economy has reached autarky, and no longer needs its people to engage with the outside world. We are seeing it already shutting down large companies, and shutting down all uncontrollable social media avenues, like gaming. 
Hong Kong has meant it can no longer convince the people of Taiwan that China sticks to its promises, so it's a lost cause, with war the only way to get it back. The added instability to an already unstable domestic environment means war is not on its short to medium term agenda. And the rapid fall of Afghanistan will have only reminded it of how quickly regimes fall - China lives in fear of becoming another USSR. 
USA will want to drive home its advantage, and no longer distracted by lesser conflicts, like Afghanistan, it will focus on containing China. To that end, it will beef up its control of independent states around China - one being Taiwan. That means leaning on allies to support Taiwan while internal strifes distract China. 
With the Western vaccines breaking the link between Covid and death, it can get back to normal and get on with foreign policy. 
China has shown Europe it does not honour contracts, and a country that does that, cannot be invested in, making further trade with China a lost cause. So Europe may as well look elsewhere in the area, and that is Taiwan. 
So yes, the driver is there for the EU to open negotiations with Taiwan on an investment agreement before 1st Jan 2021.

This forecast is based on:
1-Lindy effect will take place on this delayed agreement since 2013 (The more the tension,The more the delay to last!). 2-E.U-U.S Vs PRC : A.Since March 2019, the European Union has referred to China as a "systemic rival".
(https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-slams-china-as-systemic-rival-as-trade-tension-rises/) 3-In March 2021, it was reported that there would be serious doubts about the approval of the Comperehensive Agreement deal which was made in 2013 in the European Parliament given China's sanctions against members of the parliament:
https://www.politico.eu/article/china-throws-eu-trade-deal-to-the-wolf-warriors-sanctions-investment-pact/ 4-In May 2021, the European Commission announced plans to reduce dependence on China in strategic areas of the economy:
https://www.reuters.com/world/china/eu-executive-slows-push-china-investment-deal-2021-05-05/ 5**On 20th of May,  the E.U Parliament froze ratification of the CA until Beijing lifts sanctions which I  gave 1:3% only.

Dropping my probability a bit. 
I feel like this will happen, but not in the time period.
The new EU China strategy has been released
https://oeil.secure.europarl.europa.eu/oeil/popups/ficheprocedure.do?reference=2021/2037(INI)&l=en
It has been voted on and ratified by the EU Foreign Affairs committee and is going to the full Parliament in September. It re states that MEPs want the euro commission to begin work towards a Taiwan agreement. I expect that the EC will wait for this to be ratified to begin the impact assessment. 
MEPs will present a webinar on what has been done and the way forward for thee agreement at the end of September
https://www.reneweuropegroup.eu/events/2021-07-12/an-investment-agreement-with-taiwan
If the EC started the impact assessment after September I don't expect that it will progress to a recommendation to the council before 1st of Jan.
Before 1st June 2022 I might go 50% maybe higher.
Ha anyone found the "new EU china strategy" report that was due on the 15th?
today's NATO statement as a first step in communicating new blocks to western public

I don't see that happening. EU normally is passive anyways, especially now that it's fragmented. 
Thanks for comments made by @Scappleby https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1306588 and @keith-huggins https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1306078 The Parliament's foreign affairs committee is set to vote on the "new EU-China strategy" report on July 15. So, this should be interesting.  That being said, I have to learn more about the inner workings of EC.
Very unlikely. The EC does not move that quickly and there will be a number of holdout countries who would rather avoid upsetting China

while I think such a move to be likely (0.6), I think not in that timeframe, b/c
- German general election will be very recent and new political players (Baerbock) need to be brought up to speed and convinced, 
- Chinese retaliation might sway political sentiment in French general election away from Macron to Le Pen. This is probably best avoided with same reasoning as
- European public sentiment of China would need to be shifted first from vague economic opportunity to ideological threat for the expected Chinese retaliation to not severely undermine political cohesion in and between EU-Member States.
Talks or negotiations are likely. Formal authorization not.

"The Commission has previously linked the commencement of negotiations with Taiwan to first reaching an agreement with China." https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/P-9-2021-001691_EN.html "the EU remains the largest source of foreign direct investment (FDI) to Taiwan, with an accumulated value of EUR 48 billion up to 2019, accounting for 31% of Taiwan’s inward FDI" https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/AFET-PR-691427_EN.pdf "EU lawmakers are fed up with the European Commission’s reluctance to start an investment deal with Taiwan, while U.S. President Joe Biden has his sights set on trade talks with Taipei. The indecision on the part of EU policymakers — out of fear of provoking Beijing, which could tear up the hard-earned but unratified EU-China pact." 
"Brussels has been prioritizing an investment accord with Beijing but this now looks highly unlikely to be ratified amid tit-for-tat sanctions, and growing tensions over human rights abuses in Xinjiang and Hong Kong."
"China is warning the EU to stop any such work in progress. "The EU side has always insisted that it follows the One China principle. We urge the EU side not to have any official interactions in any form or nature with the Taiwan region," a spokesman for the Chinese mission to the EU"
https://www.politico.eu/article/meps-push-brussels-follow-biden-taiwan-trade-eu-parliament-china/ "The deal [CAI] was already on ice. Because of Beijing's sanctions on European officials and academics, members of the European Parliament were vowing never to ratify it." https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-trade-chief-says-efforts-to-ratify-china-deal-suspended/ "The United States and Taiwan held trade talks on Wednesday [June 30] for the first time since 2016, brushing aside China's objections to the renewed dialogue. Beijing strongly objects to any country holding economic dialogues involving Taiwan, which it views as part of its territory." https://www.politico.com/news/2021/06/30/us-taiwan-hold-first-trade-talks-since-2016-497407 "Under the One China policy, Australia doesn't officially recognise Taiwan as a sovereign state. But it supports Taiwan's involvement in international organisations, and merely "acknowledges" Beijing's position that Taiwan is a province of China. A Taiwanese diplomat wants Australia to re-think that stance, amid ongoing trade tensions and frosty diplomatic relations between China and Australia." 
"At present, Taiwan and Australia, we both rely heavily on the Chinese market for trade … But this is unsustainable and dangerous to our national security. So we really need to diversify our trade."
"Free trade negotiations with Taiwan would further anger China and, I fear, continue to escalate trade friction between China and Australia,"
https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-07-07/taiwan-us-free-trade-agreement-xi-jinping-speech-australia/100269014 The whole situation seems like classic game theory. If China can keep the the world fractured on Taiwan and threaten each country individually no single country or region is likely to push back. That said, it seems talks of a US-Taiwan deal could also be a catalyst for the EU and other major trading partners. There is plenty of appetite for recognition and deals with Taiwan, but this is nothing new, and the world is so dependent on China that there are real concerns of negative escalation. Between the delayed ratification of the CAI and the long standing inertia with Taiwan over separate recognition and fear of upsetting China I would be surprised if this recommendation is made but, if tensions escalate quickly, the EU and other western powers may use opening talks as a bargaining chip/threat to push back.
Not the right timing for it…
Oh, I rather don't think so.  They can get a lot of this sort of thing done with more or less informal agreements that don't contemplate treating Taiwan as an actual country.
Mostly uncertain (feels like 20-25%), but if I had predicted on this question between 2015 and 2020 I wouldn't have been confident enough in it probably not happening.

July 15th release of the "new EU-china strategy" may be key to strengthening this forecast. Talks are already underway on policy an investment matters but formal negotiations are another thing altogether and would be a big poke at China.
I have little knowlege in this area so the reading should be fun.

Trade between Taiwan and the EU has increased by more than eightfold in the last twenty years and Taiwan has been a member of the WTO since 2002.
There is no trade deal, diplomatic or formal political relations with Taiwan due to the ‘One China’ policy. However, the EU being ever pragmatic, does trade between the two parties, but the EU does have a trade deficit with Taiwan. An investment agreement, as viewed by the EU, is perhaps a method of evening up the balance of trade. The EU’s concept of an investment agreement is as follows:
Level playing field for EU investors
Transparency in business dealings
Sustainable development, human rights, labour rights and environmental standards
Social responsibility
Responsible business practices
Attract investment into the EU
Regulate home economies in the public interest. None of which would appear to be a problem in dealing with Taiwan as the EU treats the island as a like-minded partner. But why now?
China predictably, has reacted by stating that groundless human rights claims is an excuse to halt progress on deal that would benefit European businesses and consumers.
Relations between China and the EU have soured in 2021 due to competing sanctions concerning human rights in Xinjiang and security laws in Hong Kong that resulted in stalling the proposed investment agreement between the two parties.  The question refers to a suggestion by the EU Commission to ‘open’ negotiations with Taiwan over an investment agreement. Considering the historical record of the EU process of negotiations it is quite probable that talks could possibly continue for the next seven years, that perhaps offers the EU with a bargaining chip in its negotiations/relations with China.
The EU would also be cognizant of the current talks between the Biden administration and Taiwan concerning a trade deal and will not wish to be left behind.
It is possible that given Germany’s (via Merkel) to push for an investment with China, it could block proposed talks to avoid antagonizing a major customer for its goods.
Also, China is quite capable of influencing various EU member states to use their veto (Hungary being a prime example) by exerting its economic pressure to avoid any potential of agreement talks.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-30/u-s-taiwan-to-talk-chips-vaccines-as-long-stalled-talks-begin  https://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/accessing-markets/investment/  https://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/countries-and-regions/countries/taiwan/  https://www.rfi.fr/en/international/20210507-french-senate-s-taiwan-vote-triggers-beijing-s-anger-again  https://www.rfi.fr/en/business/20210520-european-parliament-votes-to-freeze-eu-china-investment-deal-cai-human-rights-sanctions-xinjiang-hong-kong https://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/countries-and-regions/countries/taiwan/  https://borderlex.net/2021/05/26/comment-eu-taiwan-relations-in-the-indo-pacific-time-for-an-upgrade/  https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/why-europes-future-is-on-the-line-in-the-taiwan-strait/  https://www.cfr.org/blog/time-now-trade-deal-taiwan   EU to follow US not to be left out. https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-and-taiwan-set-date-to-revive-trade-and-investment-talks-11624626153  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-30/u-s-taiwan-to-talk-chips-vaccines-as-long-stalled-talks-begin

This would be a bold move that I believe is unlikely considering the agreement pending ratification with the PRC. I'm betting that the forces competing within the EU about how to proceed with  the PRC tentative agreement will nix this proposal.
